abstract: The Barwell meteorite contains large, abundant clasts that are igneous in nature. We report iodine–xenon ages of five clasts and one sample of host chondrite material. The fragment of host chondrite material yielded the oldest age determined: 4567.8 ± 1.2 Ma. Two clasts produced old, well defined ages of 4564.96 ± 0.33 Ma and 4565.60 ± 0.33 Ma. These, and a third clast having a less precise old age of 4566.0 ± 3.2 Ma, are interpreted as recording the timing of crystallisation of the samples. They were incorporated into the Barwell parent body before it underwent thermal metamorphism, but the I–Xe ages survived secondary processing on the parent body and were not reset by metamorphism, metasomatism or shock. Two further clasts record younger ages of 4560.96 ± 0.45 Ma and 4554.22 ± 0.38 Ma. These samples contain a high abundance of albitic mesostasis, and the most likely explanation of the ages is that they record the timing of metasomatism on the parent body. We also analysed four host chondrite samples that do not give I–Xe ages: in these samples, the system appears to have been disturbed by shock. It has been suggested previously that the igneous clasts are derived from an early generation of partially melted asteroids. We do not have direct evidence that the clasts we examined were necessarily derived from a partially differentiated body, only that they were derived from cooling of a silicate melt; the clasts could thus be the products of any one of several proposed models for chondrule formation. Our results indicate that processes akin to chondrule formation, in that they involve rapid cooling of a silicate melt, were ongoing at the same time as CAI formation, lending support to the suggestion that Al–Mg chondrule ages indicate either heterogeneous distribution of 26Al or resetting of the Al–Mg system after chondrule formation.

author_highlights.sentence: Four Barwell samples have crystallization ages within 2 Ma of CAI formation.
Younger ages in two samples reflect parent body metamorphism and metasomatism.
Igneous clasts could be derived from disruption of a partially molten planetesimal.
Chondrules and some igneous clasts may have formed by the same mechanism.

body_text.sentence: The ages of the oldest samples we have dated here (BCL2, BCL4, BCL5 and BCH3) are either before or during the period the model predicts the chondritic crust to be accreting, and are therefore too old to be explained by this model: the disruption predicted by the model occurs too late to account for the ages of these samples.

body_text.sentence: In this model, impact disruption of the parent body could scramble the metallic core, achondritic mantle and chondrite crust, and the inclusions we observe in chondrite meteorites could, in fact, have originated from the same parent body as the host meteorite.

body_text.sentence: Assuming that the Barwell clasts do indeed represent this type of material, the I–Xe ages add further weight to the evidence from 26Al–26Mg data for eucrites, mesosiderites and angrites (Amelin, 2008; Bizzarro et al., 2005; Connelly et al., 2008; Schiller et al., 2015), and Hf–W data for magmatic iron meteorites (Kleine et al., 2005; Markowski et al., 2006; Scherstén et al., 2006) for a generation of parent bodies which formed and differentiated very early, and were subsequently disrupted, before the formation of the chondrite parent bodies.

body_text.sentence: An alternative, perhaps controversial, model to the traditional concept of chondrite and achondrite meteorites having originated from different parent bodies, is that both could have originated from the same parent body: a differentiated core surrounded by an unmelted, chondritic crust (Weiss and Elkins-Tanton, 2013 and references therein).

body_text.sentence: Iron meteorites also record early differentiation: Hf–W data from magmatic iron meteorites imply the iron meteorite parent bodies probably accreted within ∼0.3 Ma of CAI formation (Kruijer et al., 2014), and that differentiation and core formation in the oldest iron meteorites occurred within ∼2 Ma of CAI formation (Burkhardt et al., 2012; Davis and McKeegan, 2014; Kleine et al., 2005; Markowski et al., 2006; Scherstén et al., 2006).
